issue.title: The site can't provide a secure connection: https://localhost:4433
issue.body:
Hello Team,
I have bult the chromium demo un ubuntu server but at the last step i have recived the error "The site can't provide a secure connection". Client ans server dont support the common ssl.
I am able to successfully rin the TLS connection in boringssl

![BoringSSL_passed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28886647/85852131-9f7a6a00-b7cd-11ea-94f6-c074d073caff.jpg)
![Error on local host](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28886647/85852186-b7ea8480-b7cd-11ea-97aa-a303e6a5574b.jpg)

comment.body:
Hello Team,

The chromium version is correct and we followed the same steos as mentioned in the document. But no luck :(

issue.title: Integrated latest SIKE bug fixes
issue.body: Integrated SIKE upstream commits from 521aab to 50f352, including a fix for a crash when fed garbage data. Fixes issue #788.

comment.body:
> Do we know if it passes #787? If so, we could just put them both in one PR. If not, then further fixes may be required.

It does locally. It felt like differently scoped PRs, but I see your point. Let me add the extra test code to this PR...

issue.title: Enable automated upstream imports
issue.body:
This is adding capabilities to `copy_from_pqclean` to alternatively automatically import upstream code bases.

This PR is an "empty" run (without actual upstream additions) to ease review. When approved, it will be used to import new upstream versions of `kyber` and `dilithium` (setting the corresponding environment variables listed in the `copy_from_pqclean.yml` file to the folders of the upstream repositories along the same lines as is done for a `PQClean` import). 

But by no means this facility is restricted to those algorithms. The basic idea is to have `META.yml` files modelled on the ones used by `PQClean` within the upstream repositories: These contain 
- names of files to import
- possible compile directives
- possibly changed & properly namespace'd algorithm entry points  
- possibly changed KATs. Any such KAT changes will be called out when running the new script variant to ensure library version bumps can be initiated.

A more complete documentation of this will be added to [the Wiki](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Contributing-guide) when merged. Conceptually, this could be used to automatically introduce any new/changed algorithms provided the upstream code maintainer provides NIST-like APIs and these ".yml-import-drivers".

CCI [ran successfully here](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/baentsch/liboqs/307/workflows/742d5394-1bd1-4acd-b89a-78e365753c40)

All files changed outside of `copy_from_pqclean` have the facility added to provide their own compile directives and to allow for their own versions of otherwise common includes (generated by new `copy_from_pqclean`).

A minor correction is also done to `scripts/copy_from_pqclean/src/sig/sig.h/algs_length.fragment` to cater for the new number of algorithms not imported from PQClean.

comment.body: @xvzcf I'd like to merge this in tomorrow -- so if you'd be able to spend a few minutes looking this over today that would be most beneficial. Thanks in advance!

issue.title: Enable automated upstream imports
issue.body:
This is adding capabilities to `copy_from_pqclean` to alternatively automatically import upstream code bases.

This PR is an "empty" run (without actual upstream additions) to ease review. When approved, it will be used to import new upstream versions of `kyber` and `dilithium` (setting the corresponding environment variables listed in the `copy_from_pqclean.yml` file to the folders of the upstream repositories along the same lines as is done for a `PQClean` import). 

But by no means this facility is restricted to those algorithms. The basic idea is to have `META.yml` files modelled on the ones used by `PQClean` within the upstream repositories: These contain 
- names of files to import
- possible compile directives
- possibly changed & properly namespace'd algorithm entry points  
- possibly changed KATs. Any such KAT changes will be called out when running the new script variant to ensure library version bumps can be initiated.

A more complete documentation of this will be added to [the Wiki](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Contributing-guide) when merged. Conceptually, this could be used to automatically introduce any new/changed algorithms provided the upstream code maintainer provides NIST-like APIs and these ".yml-import-drivers".

CCI [ran successfully here](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/baentsch/liboqs/307/workflows/742d5394-1bd1-4acd-b89a-78e365753c40)

All files changed outside of `copy_from_pqclean` have the facility added to provide their own compile directives and to allow for their own versions of otherwise common includes (generated by new `copy_from_pqclean`).

A minor correction is also done to `scripts/copy_from_pqclean/src/sig/sig.h/algs_length.fragment` to cater for the new number of algorithms not imported from PQClean.

issue.body: Integrated SIKE upstream commits from 521aab to 50f352, including a fix for a crash when fed garbage data. Added extra test from PR #787. Fixes issue #788.

issue.title: Create a standalone jar
issue.body:
Bundle the native library in the liboqs-java.jar wrapper. If the native library is in java.library.path, load it directly, otherwise extract it from the jar.

Previously we had to provide the location of the native `liboqs-jni.so` to the `java.library.path` (e.g., `java -Djava.library.path=target -cp target/liboqs-java.jar:examples/ KEMExample`). Now the `liboqs-jni.so` is also packaged inside the generated jar and the java code loads it dynamically if it is not found in the java.library.path.

Example usage:
```
javac -cp target/liboqs-java.jar examples/KEMExample.java
java -cp target/liboqs-java.jar:examples/ KEMExample
```

@christianpaquin We can now also add the generated liboqs-java.jar in the release.

comment.body:
I tried on my ubuntu systems, and I get the following: when I build liboqs without a system install (i.e., without running `ninja install`), then I get an error either when running:
`mvn package -P linux -Dliboqs.include.dir="/mnt/c/dev/github/liboqs/build/include" -Dliboqs.lib.dir="/mnt/c/dev/github/liboqs/build/lib"`:

```
[ERROR] Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0.087 s <<< FAILURE! - in org.openquantumsafe.KEMTest
[ERROR] org.openquantumsafe.KEMTest  Time elapsed: 0.083 s  <<< ERROR!
java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /tmp/oqs-native-lib6100570168600381311/liboqs-jni.so: liboqs.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory at org.openquantumsafe.KEMTest.init(KEMTest.java:23)
```

or when running the KEMExample after skipping the tests in the `mvn` command (`-Dmaven.test.skip=true`):

`Exception in thread "main" java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /tmp/oqs-native-lib12867457990569856798/liboqs-jni.so: liboqs.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

Basically, the same error in both cases, can't find OQS even though it is located in the location I specified in `-Dliboqs.include.dir`. Do you observe the same thing?

issue.title: Added invalid ciphertext test in test_kem
issue.body:
Test now generates a random ciphertext and expect an invalid decapsulation or non-matching shared secret. Also replaced invalid signature with random array vs one with only the first byte modified (to potentially catch more errors).

- [ ] Fix SIKE compressed decapsulation error on bad data before merging this (issue #788)

comment.body: These changes have been incorporated in PR #790.

issue.title: Create a standalone jar
issue.body:
Bundle the native library in the liboqs-java.jar wrapper. If the native library is in java.library.path, load it directly, otherwise extract it from the jar.

Previously we had to provide the location of the native `liboqs-jni.so` to the `java.library.path` (e.g., `java -Djava.library.path=target -cp target/liboqs-java.jar:examples/ KEMExample`). Now the `liboqs-jni.so` is also packaged inside the generated jar and the java code loads it dynamically if it is not found in the java.library.path.

Example usage:
```
javac -cp target/liboqs-java.jar examples/KEMExample.java
java -cp target/liboqs-java.jar:examples/ KEMExample
```

@christianpaquin We can now also add the generated liboqs-java.jar in the release.

comment.body:
I observe the same issue but that is not caused by this PR. If you do not install liboqs in `/usr/local/lib` the native C code is not able to find it in runtime. The solution to this is to set the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` and then it will work no mattter where liboqs is installed (e.g., `export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/home/jimouris/Downloads/lib"`).

This is not specific to the java wrapper though, for example [liboqs-go](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-go#runningbuilding-on-posix-linuxunix-like-platforms) and [liboqs-python](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-python#installation) also require setting the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`.

Ah ok, I misunderstood this PR; I though it would get rid of this requirement by packaging the library in the jar. Ok, then, works for me if I set the library path.

issue.body:
Bundle the native library in the liboqs-java.jar wrapper. If the native library is in java.library.path, load it directly, otherwise extract it from the jar.

Previously we had to provide the location of the native `liboqs-jni.so` to the `java.library.path` (e.g., `java -Djava.library.path=target -cp target/liboqs-java.jar:examples/ KEMExample`). comment.body: Ah, I see. I placed the `liboqs-jni.so` in the jar, which is the library generated by the native code of the wrapper in order to call the liboqs C functions.
